Title:
Two new corticioid species: Hyphoderma sinense and H.
floccosum spp. nov. (Hyphodermataceae, Polyporales) from southern
China
Keywords:
molecular phylogeny, taxonomy, wood-rotting fungi, Yunnan
Province
Abstract:
Two new corticioid fungal species, Hyphoderma sinense and
H. floccosum spp. nov., are proposed based on a combination of
morphological features and molecular evidence. Hyphoderma sinense is
characterized by an annual growth habit, resupinate basidiomata with
smooth hymenial surface, a monomitic hyphal system with generative
hyphae bearing clamp connections, IKI, CB, presence of encrusted and
moniliform cystidia and cylindrical to allantoid, colorless,
thin-walled, smooth, basidiospores measuring as 811.5 × 35 µm.
Hyphoderma floccosum is characterized by resupinate basidiomata with
farinaceous hymenial surface, a monomitic hyphal system with generative
hyphae bearing clamp connections, and tubular cystidia and leptocystidia
and ellipsoid to allantoid, colorless, thin-walled, smooth
basidiospores. Sequences of ITS+nLSU nrRNA gene regions of the studied
samples were generated and phylogenetic analyses were performed with
maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony and Bayesian inference methods.
These phylogenetic analyses based on molecular data of ITS+nLSU
sequences showed that two new species clustered into Hyphoderma, in
which H. sinense grouped with H. transiens, and H. floccosum grouped
with a clade comprising H. pinicola, H. setigerum and H.
subsetigerum.
